prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Polarization
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is intended for dust continuum polarization observations of the Young Stellar Objects in B59. The technical setup consists of 4 spectral windows in TDM mode in Band 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral setup is Band 6 continuum observations (TDM) in full polarization mode. This setup provides 4 spectral windows with 1.8 GHz bandwidth each and uniform (low) spectral resolution of 62.5 MHz. Band 6 was chosen for providing a compromise for sampling the envelope and disk scales simultaneously.

The desired spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec corresponds to a physical size of ~ 40 AU (assuming a distance of ~ 145 pc to the Pipe nebula, Alves & Franco 2007). The largest angular scale was inferred from SMA compact observations of source BHB07-11 (Hara et al. 2013). This source is a Class 0 object where the observed emission arises mostly from a dust envelope of ~ 3.5 - 4 arcsec. This setup enables us to resolve the polarization across the circumstellar disk of the Class I/II objects and trace the dust envelopes of Class 0 objects up to ~ 510 AU. The Class I/II sources are expected to be more compact because the emission arises mostly from their disks. In any case, the sources are smaller than 1/3 the primary beam of band 6 (~ 8 arcseconds).

The proposed catalog comprises YSO at Classes 0, I and II. Table 1 shows peak fluxes at single-dish angular resolutions (~ 11 arcseconds). We consider that 50% and 70% of this flux comes from a 100 AU circumstellar disk (e. g., Rao et al. 2014) for the younger (BHB07-11 and BHB07-10) and more evolved (BHB07-09 and BHB07-01) objects, respectively. The mean disk intensity (averaged over the four sources) is about 110 mJy across 0.67 arcseconds (100 AU at the Pipe nebula distance). Therefore, for the requested resolution of 0.3 arcseconds (44 AU), the peak flux is 22 mJy/beam. Assuming a conservative 1% polarization level (0.22 mJy/beam), and to detect the half maximum of the polarization peak at 5-sigma, our requested rms is 0.022 mJy/beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Molecular line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Scienge Goal aims to trace the local kinematics in each object using Band 6. The molecular tracers are CO (outflow), C18O (dense gas) and H2CO (dense and warm gas). One spectral window is selected for continuum emission only.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The rms estimation is done for line-free channels in the C18O spectral window. We based our estimation on this molecule because it traces the kinematics of the dense gas. C18O is optically thin with respect to CO(2-1), and therefore shows more contrast. The extended emission is filtered out by the interferometer, so we see the denser zones. The C18O emission from source BHB07-11 as observed by the Submillimeter Array (Hara te al. 2013) can be extrapolated to the other targets using the ratio between the dust emission of this source with respect to the others (using the intrinsic dust emission fluxes of Roman-Zuniga et al. 2012), i. e.,
Flux_c18o_source = Flux_c18o_BHB07-11 * (Flux_dust_source/Flux_dust_BHB07-11)
where Flux_c18o_source is the C18O flux density for all sources (except BHB07-11), Flux_c18o_BHB07-11 is the C18O flux density for BHB07-11, Flux_dust_source is the dust emission flux density for all sources (except BHB07-11) and Flux_dust_BHB07-11 is the dust emission flux density for BHB07-11. Dust emission in high density cores is well correlated with CO emission, so this approach is valid.
Therefore, we aim for an rms of 6.5 mJy, which implies a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 30 for the source with weaker C18O emission, BHB07-10 (~ 200 mJy/beam). The required observing time is 1.3 hours (including overheads), with 11 minutes on-source time. If this proposal is successfull, we intend to integrate twice that time for the weaker source (22 minutes), and share the remaining time among the brigther sources (about 7 minutes per source). This will result in an improved SNR for the weaker source (40) at a low cost in SNR for the remaining sources (40 < SNR < 100).

The spectral setup is chosen to produce a spectral resolution of 0.33 km/s (C18O), 0.37 km/s (CO) and 0.19 km/s (H2CO). In all cases, these resolutions are achieved after spectral averaging (2 for H2CO and CO and 16 for C18O). The linewidth of the 13CO and C18O emission in the SMA maps of Hara at al. (2013) are 9 and 7 km/s, respectively (although single-dish data of Duarte-Cabral et al. 2012 show a narrower emission for C18O - 3 km/s). Thus, even in this upper limit, the selected bandwidth (80 km/s for H2CO and C18O, 600 km/s for CO) covers the entire line with high resolution. Since our spectral setup includes channel averaging, the project is not datarate demanding. The fourth available baseband will be used for continuum emission (TDM mode). This window will be used for self-calibration.

For consistency, the desired spatial resolution and largest angular scale are the same of the polarization Science Goal. The CO emission in the SMA maps of Hara et al. (2013) are considerably extended (15"), but we want to focus only on the local kinematics in each object. At such resolution, we will be able to derive the kinematics of the dense gas and to identify the powering sources of the observed outflows.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: B59 is the only star-forming site in the quiescent and magnetized Pipe nebula. It contains a small cluster of low-mass protostars and a very twisted magnetic field in comparison with the more pristine regions of the cloud. We propose to perform a detailed dynamical study of B59 using linear polarization and molecular line observations. These data will reveal the magnetic field morphology in sources in B59 which are at distinct evolutionary stages: Class 0, I and II. We want to trace the evolution of the magnetic field properties in the three stages. We expect to resolve the field morphology at the dust envelope of Class 0 objects and at the circumstellar disks at Class I and II objects. Since all targets belong to the same (low-turbulent) parental cloud, we will be able to test predictions of magnetized molecular cloud models. As a complement, molecular line data will trace the kinematics of the cores in order to better constrain the possible ambiguity of projection effects in the polarization data. This project is a resubmission of a previous (B-ranked) Cycle 2 proposal.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals:
2013.1.00291.S, The emergent low-mass cluster B59: how to beat magnetic fields, Felipe Alves. This proposal was ranked in the 10-20% band of the submitted Cycle 2 proposals. The present proposal is intended to be a resubmission of our Cycle 2 project, given that B-ranked projects of the previous cycle will not be carried over to Cycle 3.
The present proposal has the same technical setup of the original one. Although now we use a more robust sensitivity estimation, the requested time is only slightly (~ 4%) different from the original proposal. We have taken into account the TAC comments on the previous proposal, and we have included a figure showing the modelling of dust continuum polarization data using models of magnetized cores. The absence of such an illustration was the only drawback pointed out by the TAC in the previous Cycle.
Our Cycle 2 project has not been observed by the time of submission of this proposal. If it is observed by the end of the current Cycle, and if the present proposal has granted telescope time eventually, only the observations needed for completion of the project (if any) should be considered for Cycle 3.
